questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with a 4-week history of a painful, swollen left knee. He has a past medical history of a treated sexually transmitted disease 6 months ago. On examination, there was a large effusion in the left knee. Synovial fluid analysis shows a white cell count of 15 x 10^9/L, but culture was negative. Which one of the following organisms is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Key clues:
    • Young adult with prior STD
    • Large monoarthritis (left knee)
    • Sterile culture (culture-negative effusion)
    • White cell count: 15 × 109/L in synovial fluid
  • These features strongly suggest gonococcal arthritis:
    • Pathogenesis:
      • N.gonorrhoeae spreads hematogenously → septic arthritis (usually monoarticular).
    • Classic presentation:
      • Migratory polyarthritis → monoarthritis.
      • Tenosynovitis and pustular skin lesions (may or may not be present).
    • Cultures are often negative:
      • The organism is difficult to isolate from joints because it clears from synovial fluid quickly after dissemination.
  • Why culture is negative:
    • Gonococci are fastidious and may be cleared by prior antibiotic treatment.
    • Blood cultures and mucosal (urethral/cervical) swabs are more likely to yield the organism.

Explanation of other options

Gardnella (Gardnerella vaginalis) (Option A): Causes bacterial vaginosis, not arthritis.

Chlamydia (Option B): Can cause reactive arthritis (Reiter's syndrome), but joint cultures are sterile, and there is usually a triad (arthritis, urethritis, conjunctivitis). Here, there is true septic arthritis following gonococcal infection.

Treponema pallidum (Option C): Causes syphilis, which can involve joints in tertiary stages, but presents differently and is not the typical cause of acute monoarthritis.

Multiple intracellular gram-negative diplococci

questions.text: A 38-year-old athlete has pain on abduction of her arm, particularly when resisted. Which tendon pathology is affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Key clinical feature:
    • Pain during abduction of the arm (especially 60°-120°) that worsens with resisted abduction is a hallmark of rotator cuff tendinitis.
  • Most commonly affected tendon:
    • Supraspinatus tendon (passes beneath the acromion, prone to impingement and inflammation).
  • Reason:
    • The supraspinatus initiates abduction (first 15°) and is active throughout abduction.
    • Inflammation causes a "painful arc," particularly between 60-120 degrees.

Explanation of other options:

Biceps tendonitis (Option A): Presents with pain localized to the anterior shoulder, worsened by resisted supination or forward flexion of the elbow (Speed's test). Not typically linked with pain, only during abduction.

Teres minor tendonitis (Option C): Teres minor is mainly responsible for external rotation and posterior stabilization of the humeral head, not abduction.

Infraspinatus tendinitis (Option D): Also involves external

questions.text: A 74-year-old man has significant bony pains which have been occurring for 3 years. He presents to the clinic for assessment, and the investigation results were obtained below: Corrected calcium 9.6 mg/dl, ESR 20 mm/1st hr, Alkaline phosphatase 625 iu/L (50 - 100), gamma GT 42 iu/L (10-50), Prostate specific antigen 7.4 pg/L (0-6). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key findings in this patient:

  • Normal calcium and normal phosphate
  • Very high alkaline phosphatase (ALP) with normal GGT (indicating bone source, not liver)
  • Long-standing bone pain and deformity features.

Paget's disease (osteitis deformans):

  • Typical lab pattern:
    • ↑ ALP (due to increased osteoblastic activity)
    • Normal calcium & phosphate
  • Clinical features:
    • Bone pain, deformities (skull enlargement, bowing of long bones), and hearing loss (cranial involvement).
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Accelerated bone turnover with disorganized bone remodeling.

The normal GGT confirms that the source of raised ALP is bone, not liver

Explanation of other options

Osteoporosis (Option A): All biochemical markers are usually normal (ALP is not raised). Main diagnostic test: DEXA scan. Therefore, not consistent here.

Osteomalacia (Option B): Low vitamin D → Low calcium and phosphate, and raised ALP. The patient's calcium and phosphate levels are normal, which excludes osteomalacia.

Metastatic prostatic carcinoma (Option C): Typically shows raised ALP (bone metastasis) and high PSA. PSA here is only slightly elevated (7.4 pg/L; age-related mild rise). Additionally, metastases often cause hypercalcemia, which is not present here. The clinical picture is more chronic deformity rather than acute bony metastasis pain.

questions.text: A professional tennis player presents with shoulder pains, especially whilst serving the ball. He has limited passive and active shoulder abduction to less than 60°. His temperature is 36.5°C and he has a normal white cell count. There is tenderness around the anterior portion of the shoulder joint. Which diagnosis is likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key findings:

  • Pain aggravated by abduction (especially 60°-120° arc)
  • Limitations of both active and passive abduction
  • Localized tenderness over the anterior and superior aspect of the shoulder (greater tubercle).
  • History of overhead repetitive motion (tennis serving) - classic for rotator cuff injury.

Supraspinatus tendonitis (rotator cuff tendinitis):

  • The most common cause of painful arc syndrome.
  • Mechanism: Repeated overhead activity causes inflammation of the supraspinatus tendon beneath the acromion.
  • Pain worsens during abduction between 60° and 120° (painful arc).
  • No systemic signs (afebrile, normal WBC).

Explanation of other options:

Glenohumeral joint osteoarthritis (Option A): Rare, usually in older age. Produces a global limitation of movement (not just painful arc) and crepitus. No direct association with overhead repetitive sports.

Bursitis (subacromial or subdeltoid) (Option B): Often coexists with rotator cuff tendinitis but usually causes pain even at rest and tenderness over the lateral shoulder. Less specific to the painful arc.

Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis) (Option C): Pain over lateral elbow, worsens with wrist extension and gripping. Not related to shoulder pain.

questions.text: A 39-year-old lady presents with polyuria and thirst. Her serum calcium of 10.5 mg/dl and a parathyroid hormone of 12 (1-8) pmol/l. She has normal renal function. Which test provides the best assessment for determining the severity of her bone loss?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diagnosis:

  • This patient has primary hyperparathyroidism (elevated serum calcium + elevated PTH with normal renal function).
  • Excess PTH leads to increased bone resorption, particularly affecting cortical bone.

Role of DEXA (Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry):

  • The best method to assess bone mineral density (BMD) and quantify bone loss.
  • Helps in deciding on surgical intervention (parathyroidectomy) when there is significant bone loss.

Explanation of other options:

CT of the spine (Option A): Used to detect fractures, tumors, or structural abnormalities, not quantitative BMD.

Vitamin D levels (Option C): Important to assess for secondary hyperparathyroidism, but do not measure bone loss severity.

Isotope bone scan (Option D): Detects areas of increased bone turnover but cannot quantify overall bone density. It is sensitive but not specific.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man presents with pain in his left foot. He mentions that he has had poor mobility. General examination reveals a swollen ankle. Neurological examination reveals absent ankle jerk and weak foot flexion/extension on the left. His ESR is 30 mm/hr, CRP is <5mg/l. Joint X-ray reveals subchondral fractures, soft tissue swelling, and a narrowed joint space. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The key findings are:

  • Neuropathy (absent ankle jerk, weakness)
  • X-ray changes: subchondral fractures, bone destruction, narrowed joint space
  • Swollen, unstable joint, but CRP is normal (no active infection)

Charcot joint (neuropathic arthropathy):

  • Occurs due to loss of pain and proprioception → joint undergoes repetitive microtrauma → severe destruction.
  • Causes: Diabetic neuropathy, tabes dorsalis (syphilis), syringomyelia, and leprosy.
  • Radiographic features: joint space narrowing, bone fragmentation, disorganization, and deformity.

Explanation of other options:

Osteoarthritis (Option B): Rarely affects the ankle. Neuro findings (absent reflex, weakness) are not seen.

Gout (Option C): Presents as an acute red, hot, painful joint with very high inflammation markers. Imaging shows punched-out erosions with overhanging edges, not subchondral fractures.

Juvenile chronic arthritis (Option D): Occurs in children (<16 yrs) and is unrelated to neuropathy.

questions.text: A 48-year-old secretary noticed tingling and numbness over the palmar surface of her thumb, index, and middle fingers after several hours at her computer. Pain in the same areas often occurs at night. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This presentation is classic for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS):

  • Symptoms:
    • Tingling, numbness, or burning in the median nerve distribution (thumb, index, middle fingers, and radial half of ring finger).
    • Night pain is characteristic, often waking the patient.
    • It can radiate into the forearm or upper arm in severe cases.
  • Signs:
    • Tinel sign: Tingling produced by tapping over the median nerve at the wrist.
    • Phalen's sign: Flexion of the wrist for 30-60 s reproduces symptoms.
    • Durkan's test: Symptoms provoked by direct pressure over the carpal tunnel.
    • Weakness or atrophy of the thenar muscles in severe cases.
  • Investigations:
    • Nerve conduction studies / EMG: Show slowed conduction across the carpal tunnel.
    • Ultrasound: Shows focal median nerve swelling at the wrist.
  • Treatment:
    • Activity modification, wrist splints, NSAIDs.
    • Local steroid injection for persistent symptoms.
    • Surgical decompression if refractory or with motor weakness.

Explanation of other options:

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option A): Can cause tenosynovitis leading to CTS, but by itself causes joint pain/swelling, not isolated nerve symptoms.

Gout (Option B): Causes acute monoarthritis (red, hot, swollen joint), not chronic tingling/numbness.

Dermatomyositis (Option C): Presents with proximal muscle weakness and characteristic rashes (heliotrope, Gottron's papules), not focal nerve entrapment symptoms.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman complained of pain at the base of her right thumb. There was tenderness and swelling of the right first carpo-metacarpal joint. Finkelstein's test is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is classic 1st carpometacarpal (CMC) joint osteoarthritis:

  • Key findings:
    • Pain and tenderness at the base of the thumb (1st CMC joint), especially in older women.
    • Finkelstein's test negative: Rules out De Quervain's tenosynovitis.
    • Associated with stiffness, swelling, crepitus, and sometimes radial subluxation of the metacarpal, leading to a "squared"appearance of the thumb base.
  • Why CMC joint OA is common:
    • It is a frequent site of OA in postmenopausal women due to degenerative changes from repetitive use.

Explanation of other options

Avascular necrosis of the scaphoid (Option A): Typically follows a fall on an outstretched hand. Pain is localized to the anatomical snuffbox, not the base of the thumb. Presents earlier in life, not isolated to the 1st CMC joint.

De Quervain's tenosynovitis (Option B): Pain is over the radial wrist (1st dorsal compartment) due to inflammation of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons. Positive Finkelstein's test (pain with thumb flexed into palm and wrist ulnar-deviated). Here, the test is negative.

Psoriatic arthritis (Option D): May affect small joints but usually has skin/nail psoriasis, dactylitis, or involvement of DIP joints. Isolated 1st CMC involvement is uncommon.

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady had a fall and fractured her femur. A DEXA scan shows reduced bone mineral density consistent with osteoporosis. What treatment should be given to reduce the likelihood of future fractures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has established osteoporosis with a fragility fracture (secondary prevention).

The goals of treatment are to:

  1. Reduce fracture risk
  2. Improve bone strength

Key components of therapy:

  1. Calcium and Vitamin D supplementation:
    • Essential to ensure adequate substrate for bone mineralization.
    • Vitamin D improves calcium absorption.
  2. Bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate):
    • First-line anti-resorptive therapy that inhibits osteoclast activity and reduces the risk of vertebral and non-vertebral fractures.
    • It should always be prescribed with calcium and vitamin D to maximize benefit.
  3. Lifestyle interventions:
    • Weight-bearing exercise, fall prevention, smoking/alcohol moderation.

Therefore:
For this patient, the correct management is alendronate + calcium + vitamin D.

Explanation of other options:

Alendronate alone (Option A): Inadequate if calcium and vitamin D deficiency exist; risk of hypocalcemia.

Alendronate and calcium (Option B): Vitamin D is necessary for calcium absorption and bone health.

Calcium alone (Option D): Does not address increased bone resorption; insufficient for secondary fracture prevention.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman complains of 12 months of mid and lower back pain associated with stiffness in her shoulders, wrists, small joints of the hands, hips, knees, and feet. The joint stiffness is more pronounced in the morning and lasts 2-3 hours, and is associated with severe fatigue. She also experiences occasional pins and needles affecting all of the right hand and frequent frontal and temporal headaches. Clinical examination demonstrates no synovitis but tenderness around the base of the cervical spine, across the shoulders, over the costochondral cartilages, greater trochanter, and the knee. Investigations are as follows: CRP <5 g/l, ESR 20 mm in the first hour; CK, serum immunoglobulins, and protein electrophoresis normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is fibromyalgia, a chronic, widespread pain syndrome.

Key clues from the case:

  1. Diffuse musculoskeletal pain lasting over 12 months.
  2. Tender points on examination (cervical spine, shoulders, costochondral junctions, trochanter, knees) without synovitis or joint swelling.
  3. Normal inflammatory markers (ESR/CRP) and normal CK, ruling out inflammatory myopathies and autoimmune arthritis.
  4. Fatigue, non-restorative sleep, and paraesthesias are typically associated symptoms.

These features fit fibromyalgia, which is a central pain amplification disorder, not an inflammatory disease.

Explanation of other options:

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) (Option A): Would have systemic features (rash, oral ulcers, cytopenias, positive ANA). Usually shows abnormal labs (positive ANA, low complement, etc.), unlike this case.

Polymyalgia rheumatica (Option B): Seen in patients >50 years, causes shoulder and hip girdle stiffness with markedly elevated ESR/CRP. This patient is younger (47) and has normal inflammatory markers.

Dermatomyositis (Option D): Presents with proximal muscle weakness (not pain), rash (heliotrope, Gottron papules), and elevated CK. Here, CK is normal, and weakness is not described.

questions.text: A 71-year-old lady has severe pain in the left knee and right hand. An X-ray of the hand shows osteophytes, and an X-ray of the knee was normal. On examination, she has limited left hip flexion. What should be the next investigation for the knee?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Normal X-ray but persistent severe knee pain- This suggests that structural changes in soft tissues (meniscus, cartilage, ligaments) could be responsible rather than bony abnormalities.
  • MRI is the best next step:
    • MRI can detect early osteoarthritis, cartilage loss, meniscal tears, and avascular necrosis that may not be visible on X-ray.
    • It is non-invasive and gives detailed soft tissue imaging.
  • Limited hip flexion indicates coexistent hip pathology (like OA or avascular necrosis), but for unexplained severe knee pain with a normal X-ray, MRI of the knee is still the next step.

Why not the other options?

Bone scan (Option B): Useful for detecting stress fractures, metastasis, or multifocal pathology, but less specific than MRI.

Arthroscopy (Option C): Invasive, reserved for when MRI shows intra-articular pathology requiring intervention.

CT scan (Option D): Excellent for bone detail, not ideal for soft tissue/cartilage evaluation.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman complains of pain in the upper back. On examination, there is tenderness over the D5 spine. MRI shows discitis of the D5-D6 spine with a partial collapse and with paraspinal collection. Investigations show: Hb 9.5 g/dl, WBC 11.1, platelets 520, ESR 120 mm in the first hour, CRP 250 g/lCalcium 8.8 mg/dl, Albumin 3.2 g/dlalkaline phosphatase 210 units/l, phosphate 2.4 mg/dl. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Key imaging features:
    • Discitis with collapse of adjacent vertebrae and a paraspinal collection is highly suggestive of tuberculous spondylitis.
    • TB favors the thoracic spine (D5-D6).
  • Clinical clues:
    • Gradual back pain and focal tenderness.
    • No acute trauma history.
    • Constitutional signs (weight loss, fatigue) are common but not always reported.
  • Lab findings:
    • Very high ESR and CRP.
    • Normocalcemia (rules out myeloma-associated lytic lesions).
    • Normocytic anemia with reactive thrombocytosis - common in chronic inflammation like TB.

Explanation of other options:

Multiple myeloma (Option B): Typically affects the elderly (>50 years). Imaging shows vertebral body destruction with sparing of the disc (because it's a primary marrow disease, not discitis). Often associated with hypercalcemia and a monoclonal spike on electrophoresis.

Osteoporosis (Option C): Causes wedge compression fractures but does not produce paraspinal abscesses or discitis. Labs are usually normal.

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option D): Presents with lower back pain, sacroiliitis, and bamboo spine. MRI would show syndesmophytes and sacroiliac joint fusion, not discitis with abscess.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man presents with bilaterally painful knees. He has bilateral reduced knee movements and crepitus. X-ray shows sclerosis, osteophytes, and loss of joint space. Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diagnosis: The X-ray features (loss of joint space, subchondral sclerosis, osteophytes) are classic for osteoarthritis (OA).

Guideline-based management:

  • First-line analgesic: Paracetamol (acetaminophen) is recommended initially because:
    • It has a good safety profile.
    • Lower risk of GI bleeding, renal impairment, or cardiovascular effects, which are more common with NSAIDs, particularly in the elderly.
  • NSAIDs are considered if paracetamol is ineffective, but always at the lowest effective dose and with gastroprotection if required.

Explanation of other options:

Ibuprofen (Option A): Effective, but NSAIDs carry a risk of GI ulceration, renal impairment, and cardiovascular complications, especially in the elderly.

Ibuprofen and lansoprazole (Option B): Adding a proton pump inhibitor (lansoprazole) reduces GI risk, but NSAIDs are still not first-line; they are reserved for those not controlled with paracetamol.

Codeine phosphate (Option D): Opioids are not first-line due to sedation, constipation, and dependence risk. Used only when other measures fail.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents with pain in the wrist. The pain is centred over the radial styloid and is increased by abduction of the thumb against resistance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key diagnostic clue:

  • Pain is localized over the radial styloid
  • Worsened by resisted thumb abduction
  • This is characteristic of De Quervain's tenosynovitis, an inflammation of the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis within the first dorsal compartment.

Clinical test:

  • Finkelstein's test: The thumb is flexed across the palm, and the wrist is moved into ulnar deviation; this elicits sharp pain at the radial styloid.

Epidemiology and causes:

  • More common in women (30-50 years).
  • Often linked to repetitive thumb/wrist movements (e.g., gardening, typing).

Explanation of other options:

Carpal tunnel syndrome (Option A): Presents with tingling, numbness, and pain in the median nerve distribution (thumb, index, middle fingers) and nocturnal symptoms. Pain is not localized to the radial styloid and is unrelated to thumb abduction resistance.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option B): Usually involves symmetrical small joint polyarthritis with swelling and stiffness, not isolated radial styloid pain.

Osteoarthritis (Option D): Typically affects the first carpometacarpal joint (base of thumb), causing pain with gripping or pinching, not classic pain with resisted thumb abduction.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents with bony swellings of the DIP joints on both hands. They were painful a year ago, but are now painless. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis is osteoarthritis. At the DIP joints, swellings are known as Heberden's nodes, and at the PIP joints, they are known as Bouchard's nodes.

choices.text: Ipratropium accelerates the metabolism of codeine

questions.text: A 63-year-old male is referred due to inadequate pain relief for his hip osteoarthritis. His GP has prescribed paracetamol and codeine 30 mg four times daily, but he has found little improvement in his pain relief. He has a past history of asthma for which he occasionally takes an inhaler. What is the most likely explanation for the lack of clinical efficacy associated with this medication?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • For hip osteoarthritis, a combination therapy of paracetamol with codeine is commonly used when paracetamol alone is insufficient.
  • Effective analgesic dosing: Studies show that 60 mg of codeine (with 1 g paracetamol) provides significant analgesic benefit.
  • 30 mg of codeine four times daily (total 120 mg/day) is often inadequate for moderate-to-severe OA pain. This explains why the patient is not experiencing relief.
  • There is no evidence of drug interaction or absorption issues in this case.

Explanation of other options:

Ipratropium accelerates the metabolism of codeine (Option A): Incorrect. Ipratropium is an inhaled anticholinergic bronchodilator used in asthma/COPD. It acts locally in the lungs and does not affect liver cytochrome P450 enzymes, so it does not alter codeine metabolism.

Impaired absorption of codeine (Option B): Incorrect. Codeine is well absorbed orally. There is no indication in this patient (no GI disease or malabsorption symptoms) that absorption is a problem.

Interaction of paracetamol with codeine (Option D): Incorrect. Paracetamol and codeine are often combined (co-codamol) to enhance analgesia through different mechanisms. There is no pharmacological interaction that reduces codeine's analgesic effect.

choices.text: DXA scan and treat at T-score -1.5
DXA scan and treat at T-score -2.5

questions.text: A 57-year-old lady returns for her three-month follow-up in your inflammatory arthropathy clinic. She reports satisfactory symptom relief with 10 mg prednisolone daily after failing several other disease-modifying agents. Her past medical history includes coeliac disease and Smith's fracture. You advise that this may be her long-term treatment of choice. Regarding preservation of bone mineral density, which further measures are necessary before proceeding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has multiple risk factors for osteoporosis:

  • Long-term glucocorticoid therapy (>3 months)
  • Coeliac disease (causes secondary osteoporosis due to malabsorption)
  • History of a fragility fracture (Smith's fracture)

Why Alendronate directly (without DEXA scan):

  • Long-term steroids increase bone resorption and reduce bone formation.
  • National guidelines (e.g., NICE, ACR) recommend starting bisphosphonate prophylaxis immediately in patients on long-term glucocorticoids who already have a fragility fracture, without waiting for DEXA results.
  • Alendronate (70 mg weekly) is the drug of choice unless contraindicated.

Explanation of other options:

Calcichew D3 forte (Option B): Calcium + vitamin D is important as an adjunct, but alone, it is insufficient in someone already at high risk. Bisphosphonates are mandatory in this context.

DXA scan and treat at T-score -1.5 (Option C): In glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis, treatment is sometimes considered at a higher threshold (T-score 1.5) if no fracture exists. However, this patient already has a fragility fracture → treatment should be started without waiting for a scan.

DXA scan and treat at T-score -2.5 (Option D): This is the standard threshold for primary osteoporosis, not for steroid-induced osteoporosis. In steroid users, intervention occurs earlier.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presents with a one-year history of worsening bilateral, anterior knee pain. The pain increases on climbing stairs. Both knees are stiff for five to 10 minutes in the morning. There is no history of knee swelling. The pain is partially controlled by paracetamol 1 g up to four times a day. She has a history of diabetes and angina. On examination, she is overweight. There is crepitus during active and passive movement of both knees. There is no knee effusion. A recent knee X-ray shows joint space narrowing in the medial tibio-femoral joint. What is the next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diagnosis: Osteoarthritis of the knee

  • Clinical features:
    • Bilateral anterior knee pain worsened by climbing stairs
    • Short-lived stiffness (<30 min)
    • Crepitus and joint space narrowing on X-ray
    • No effusion
  • Current treatment: Paracetamol with partial control.
  • Guideline-based management (NICE):
    • Core strategies: Exercise, weight reduction, footwear modification, physiotherapy.
    • First-line pharmacological treatment:
      • Paracetamol (already tried)
      • Topical NSAIDs (preferred next step, especially for knee/hand OA).
    • Oral NSAIDs/COX-2 inhibitors: Reserved for persistent symptoms because of systemic risks (CV and GI).
  • Topical NSAIDs:
    • Effective for local pain
    • Minimal systemic absorption → safer for patients with comorbidities (diabetes, angina).

Explanation of other options:

Acupuncture (Option A): NICE guidelines explicitly recommend against electro-acupuncture for osteoarthritis, as evidence does not support benefit.

Oral NSAIDs (Option B): Next step only if paracetamol and topical NSAIDs are insufficient. This patient has angina and diabetes, making systemic NSAIDs relatively risky.

Rest (Option C): Rest is not recommended. Instead, exercise and physiotherapy are key parts of OA management to maintain joint function.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with a six-day history of sharp shooting pain radiating from his back to the lateral aspect of his leg. The pain is associated with pins and needles. On examination, he has sensory loss on the lateral aspect of the leg, dorsum of the foot, and there is a partial foot drop. Which lumbar spine nerve root is affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key findings:

  • Pain radiating down lateral leg to dorsum of foot → L5 dermatome
  • Sensory loss over the lateral leg and dorsum of the foot
  • Weakness of dorsiflexion (partial foot drop)

L5 root involvement:

  • Dermatome: Lateral leg + dorsum of foot (except lateral border)
  • Myotome:
    • Extensor hallucis longus (toe dorsiflexion)
    • Tibialis anterior (ankle dorsiflexion, with L4)
    • Gluteus medius (hip abduction)
  • Reflexes: No reliable deep tendon reflex for L5 (plantar reflex involves multiple roots).

Explanation of other options:

L2 (Option A): Dermatome: Upper anterior and medial thigh. It would not affect the lateral leg or foot.

L3 (Option B): Dermatome: Mid anterior thigh and medial thigh. Reflex: Patellar (L3-4). No foot dorsum involvement.

L4 (Option C): Dermatome: Medial leg and knee. Weakness: Tibialis anterior (ankle dorsiflexion), but sensory loss would be medial, not lateral.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman presents with increasing lower back pain for the last six months. The pain is increased by working as a floor-layer, and is worse in the evening. There is no weight loss, night pain, or fever. Her back is stiff for 15 minutes in the morning. Over the last few months, she has developed firm to hard swelling on several distal and proximal interphalangeal joints, and has anterior knee pain worsened by climbing stairs. A full blood count, ESR, and CRP done by the GP have been normal. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This presentation is typical of generalised osteoarthritis (GOA):

  • Multiple joint involvement:
    • Distal and proximal interphalangeal joints (bony swellings = Heberden's and Bouchard's nodes).
    • Patellofemoral joint involvement: Anterior knee pain is worse on climbing stairs.
    • Spinal degenerative changes: Low back pain worse with activity and minimal morning stiffness (<30 min).
  • Inflammatory markers (ESR/CRP) are normal.
  • Pain is mechanical (worse with use, better with rest).

Explanation of other options:

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option A): Typically affects young men (<40 yrs). Presents with significant early morning stiffness (>30 min) and improves with activity. Inflammatory back pain pattern, sacroiliitis on imaging. Not associated with DIP/PIP joint involvement.

Discitis (Option B): Presents with constant severe pain (often night pain), systemic features like fever, and markedly raised inflammatory markers. Not a chronic 6-month course with normal inflammatory markers.

Metastasis (Option D): Would present with night pain, systemic red flags (weight loss, malaise), and neurological deficits. No evidence of this here.

questions.text: A 53-year-old female presents complaining of bone pains and muscular weakness. Her gait is waddling in nature. An X-ray pelvis was taken and is shown in the image below. Investigations show Serum corrected calcium: 8.2 mg/dL, Phosphate: 1.33 mg/dL, Alkaline phosphatase: 230 U/L, Parathyroid hormone (PTH): 180 pg/mL (elevated). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Clinical features: Bone pain, muscular weakness, waddling gait, and pseudofractures (Looser zones) are classic for osteomalacia.
  • Biochemical findings:
    • Low-normal calcium (8.2 mg/dL)
    • Low phosphate (1.33 mg/dL)
    • Elevated ALP (230 U/L) → increased osteoblastic activity attempting mineralization
    • Elevated PTH (180 pg/mL) → secondary hyperparathyroidism due to chronic hypocalcemia from vitamin D deficiency
  • Radiology: Pseudofractures (Looser zones) commonly seen in pubic rami, femoral neck, ribs (image reference below).
  • Etiology: Vitamin D deficiency (malabsorption, liver/renal disease) or phosphate deficiency.

Explanation of other options:

Pseudohypoparathyroidism (Option A): Usually shows hypocalcemia + hyperphosphatemia, often with skeletal features of Albright’s hereditary osteodystrophy.

Secondary hyperparathyroidism (Option B): Often due to chronic kidney disease; presents with hyperphosphatemia, unlike this patient.

Osteopetrosis (Option C): Characterized by increased bone density and fragility, not pseudofractures; ALP may be normal.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of multiple myeloma has a serum calcium of 11.6 mg/dl. She is prescribed pamidronate infusion over 4 days. What is its mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pamidronate is a nitrogen-containing bisphosphonate used to treat hypercalcemia of malignancy and bone lesions in multiple myeloma.
  • Mechanism:
    • Binds to bone mineral and is taken up by osteoclasts during bone resorption.
    • Induces osteoclast apoptosis, reducing bone resorption and calcium release.
    • Nitrogen-containing bisphosphonates also inhibit the mevalonate pathway, impairing osteoclast function.

Explanation of other options:

Promotes calcitonin (Option A): Calcitonin can lower calcium, but pamidronate does not act via calcitonin.

Increases calcitriol levels (Option B): Calcitriol (active vitamin D) increases calcium absorption, opposite of the desired effect in hypercalcemia.

Inhibit osteoblasts (Option D): Pamidronate does not inhibit osteoblasts; it specifically targets osteoclasts.

questions.text: A 74-year-old has had increasing back and leg pains for several years. X-rays reveal bony sclerosis of the sacroiliac, lower vertebral, and upper tibial regions. He mentions greater difficulty hearing over the recent years. Blood tests reveal an elevated serum alkaline phosphatase. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Key features supporting Paget's disease:

  • Bone pain: chronic, progressive.
  • X-ray findings: bony sclerosis and thickened trabeculae affecting the pelvis, spine, and tibia.
  • Hearing loss: due to skull involvement (compression of CN VIII).
  • Biochemistry: isolated raised alkaline phosphatase (from increased bone turnover); calcium and phosphate are usually normal.
  • Common sites: pelvis, spine, femur, skull, tibia.

Explanation of other options:

Osteoarthritis (Option B): Causes mechanical joint pain, osteophytes, and narrowing of joint spaces. Does not cause diffuse bony sclerosis or elevated ALP. No hearing loss.

Osteomalacia (Option C): Associated with vitamin D deficiency, leading to soft bones. Lab: low calcium, low phosphate, high ALP. X-rays show Looser's zones/pseudofractures, not patchy sclerosis.

Monoclonal gammopathy of uncertain significance (MGUS) (Option D): Can cause bone pain if it progresses to myeloma, but labs would show M-protein, hypercalcemia, and lytic lesions (not sclerotic). Does not present with isolated ALP elevation or hearing loss.
